title: 107_s2187
content: The Act titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002" authorizes the Department to provide healthcare during major disasters and medical emergencies. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide hospital care and medical services during major disasters and emergencies, regardless of veterans' enrollment status. This is authorized under the "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002." The Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs can provide care and services to veterans without considering their enrollment status. Priority may be given to veterans for care over other eligible groups, except for those with service-connected disabilities and active duty members receiving health-care services. Reimbursement for care provided to federal government employees will be based on agreed-upon rates. Amounts received will be credited to the facility that provided the care. The Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs can provide care and services to veterans without considering their enrollment status. Reimbursement for care provided to federal government employees will be based on agreed-upon rates and credited to the facility that provided the care. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress within 60 days of a disaster or emergency regarding the allocation of facilities and personnel for care and services. Regulations governing the exercise of the Secretary's authority under this section will be prescribed. During major disasters and medical emergencies, the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs can provide emergency care without charges. Members of the Armed Forces can receive hospital care and medical services during wars, national emergencies, or disasters. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs can offer free emergency care and medical services to active duty Armed Forces members. Priority may be given to this group over others, except for veterans with service-connected disabilities. The terms 'hospital care', 'nursing home care', and 'medical services' are defined in the section.
